Idiom: Air tenang jangan disangka tiada buaya
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Proverbial clause; negative imperative with metaphorical noun phrase
Figurative Meaning: Don’t underestimate quiet or calm people; danger or strength may be hidden beneath gentleness.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: Jangan pandang rendah orang yang nampak lemah.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Derived from Malay coastal communities observing crocodile behavior in still waters.
First Example Sentence: Mak aku selalu kato, ‘air tenang jangan disangka tiada buaya’ bila nok ingatkan aku jangan leka.
Second Example Sentence: Jangan dok pandai-pandai, ingat doh ‘air tenang jangan disangka tiada buaya’.
Third Example Sentence: Dio nampok lembut, tapi ‘air tenang jangan disangka tiada buaya’.

Figurative Meaning: Two people or things that can’t get along or mix well.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Commonly used across the Malay Peninsula to describe incompatible pairs.
First Example Sentence: Dua beradik tu bak air dengan minyak, asyik nok gado jah.
Second Example Sentence: Mu tahu doh, kito dua ni bak air dengan minyak, takleh lama-lama sebumbung.
Third Example Sentence: Bos baru tu ngan staf lame bak air dengan minyak, tiap hari ado hal.

Figurative Meaning: Desiring things you don’t really need; greed based on appearance.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: Suka benda sebab nampak lawa walaupun tak perlu.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Refers to impulsive buying behavior, especially during festive markets.
First Example Sentence: Aku ni lapar mata betul, tengok kasut lawa terus beli.
Second Example Sentence: Mak maroh sebab aku lapar mata kat pasar malam.
Third Example Sentence: Dio beli barang tak guna, lapar mata jah tu.

Idiom: Masuk telinga kanan, keluar telinga kiri
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Common Southeast Asian metaphor for selective hearing.
First Example Sentence: Aku nasihat dio hari-hari, tapi masuk telinga kanan keluar telinga kiri.
Second Example Sentence: Anok aku ni dok reti dengo, masuk telinga kanan keluar telinga kiri jah.
Third Example Sentence: Kalau mu nok berjayo, jangan jadi jenis masuk telinga kanan keluar telinga kiri.

Figurative Meaning: Trying to fix something but making it worse.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: Buat sesuatu tanpa ilmu sampai rosak lagi teruk.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Originates from Malay folktales teaching humility and skill.
First Example Sentence: Dio nok baiki kipah, last-last jadi macam tikus baiki labu.
Second Example Sentence: Jangan dok pandai-pandai, nanti jadi macam tikus baiki labu.
Third Example Sentence: Aku cuba repair motor tu, tapi hasilnya... tikus baiki labu doh.

Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Common Southeast Asian metaphor connecting pride with inflated head imagery.
First Example Sentence: Sejak dio naik pangkat, makin besar kepala.
Second Example Sentence: Budok tu baru menang sikit, dah besar kepala doh.
Third Example Sentence: Aku tak suka orang besar kepala, rasa dok selesa nak sembang.

Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Refers to Malay expressive gestures of regret or loss.
First Example Sentence: Tak beli masa murah dulu, sekarang gigit jari la.
Second Example Sentence: Aku tengok orang lain menang, aku gigit jari jah.
Third Example Sentence: Kalau mu tak usaha, nanti gigit jari sendiri.

Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Imperative clause; negation with reflexive verb
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Refers to traditional Malay cultural value of restraint.
Second Example Sentence: Orang tegur sikit terus melatah, dok molek lagu tu.
Third Example Sentence: Kalau mu jadi pemimpin, jangan cepat melatah.

Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Agricultural metaphor reflecting betrayal by protectors.
First Example Sentence: Orang kepercayaan sendiri tikam belakang, harap pagar pagar makan padi doh.
Second Example Sentence: Kisah politik negara ni macam harap pagar pagar makan padi.
Third Example Sentence: Kalau orang dalam sendiri bocor rahsia, tu harap pagar pagar makan padi la.

Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Derived from traditional Malay riverbank imagery symbolizing unity.
First Example Sentence: Kito hidup ni keno bagai aur dengan tebing, baru kuat.
Second Example Sentence: Projek ni berjayo sebab kito kerja bagai aur dengan tebing.
Third Example Sentence: Dalam keluarga, penting doh bagai aur dengan tebing.
